content.raw:
You can have just one line:

`<markdown version="1.9-">components/tutorial.md</markdown>`

Which means the tutorial is valid for version 1.9 and above.
content.html:
You can have just one line:

<markdown version="1.9-">components/tutorial.md</markdown>

Which means the tutorial is valid for version 1.9 and above.

content.raw: fixed but I'm not sure that this will be easy to understand for the users.
content.html: fixed but I'm not sure that this will be easy to understand for the users.

content.raw: We could add more information to the website. Ideas?
content.html: We could add more information to the website. Ideas?

content.raw:
Brainstorming:

```
a) Versions: 1.9, 2.x, 3.x
or
b) Versions: 1.9..3.x
or
c) Versions: from 1.9 to 3.x
or
d) Versions: 1.9 and above
or
e) Versions: 1.9..latest
or
f) Versions: 1.9+
```
a) and c) are my favourites, but this is totally subjective.
content.html:
Brainstorming:

a) Versions: 1.9, 2.x, 3.x
or
b) Versions: 1.9..3.x
or
c) Versions: from 1.9 to 3.x
or
d) Versions: 1.9 and above
or
e) Versions: 1.9..latest
or
f) Versions: 1.9+

a) and c) are my favourites, but this is totally subjective.

content.raw:
We need a mechanism that allows a tutorial to cover a single version, or multiple versions. For example, the quick start tutorial covers 1.9 and above.

we could replace the "-" with a "+" for instances where there is no following number, and then use the "-" when indicating a range, and no symbol for a single version.
content.html:
We need a mechanism that allows a tutorial to cover a single version, or multiple versions. For example, the quick start tutorial covers 1.9 and above.

we could replace the "-" with a "+" for instances where there is no following number, and then use the "-" when indicating a range, and no symbol for a single version.

content.raw:
Right, for a single version no symbol is just fine. For a range the "-"  or "..." are both ok, or even "to".

To specify "and above", is there any technical limitation to use a string? From a design point of view, seems like there is enough space to be verbose like "1.9 and above". If technical limitation is stopping us from using a string, 1.9+ looks clearer to me.
content.html:
Right, for a single version no symbol is just fine. For a range the "-" or "..." are both ok, or even "to".

To specify "and above", is there any technical limitation to use a string? From a design point of view, seems like there is enough space to be verbose like "1.9 and above". If technical limitation is stopping us from using a string, 1.9+ looks clearer to me.

content.raw: Sounds good. How about we use the "-" and "+" operators in the XML file. We can replace those symbols with other text when displayed.
content.html: Sounds good. How about we use the "-" and "+" operators in the XML file. We can replace those symbols with other text when displayed.

content.raw: uuh perfect. I will send the PR to change all the "-" by "+". Thanks.
content.html: uuh perfect. I will send the PR to change all the "-" by "+". Thanks.

content.raw: The `manifest.xml` got a little more complicated. You'll have to add your tutorial to a `category` as well, located at the end of the file. The `Get Started` category is probably good.
content.html: The manifest.xml got a little more complicated. You'll have to add your tutorial to a category as well, located at the end of the file. The Get Started category is probably good.
